instruction: What metric was chosen and how far can this metric go in classifying the anesthetized state in the related study for the classification of the maintenance/emergence states of anesthesia?
Output:
The metric chosen in the study was functional near infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS). This technique measures changes in oxygenated (HbO(2)) and deoxygenated hemoglobin (HHb) concentration and blood volume in the prefrontal cortex (PFC). These changes were found to be associated with the transition between the maintenance and emergence states during sevoflurane general anesthesia.

The study found that fNIRS-derived features, such as the locally derived mean total hemoglobin, standard deviation of HbO(2), minimum and range of HbO(2) and HHb, were correlated with the effects of sevoflurane and carried information that allowed for real-time and automatic classification of the anesthetized state with high accuracy.

Therefore, the chosen metric of fNIRS, along with the identified features, was able to accurately classify the anesthetized state during maintenance and emergence with 94.7% accuracy using a non-linear machine learning model.
